data.title: Political Leaders: European Union
data.text:
Historical development: There were three European Communities: European Coal and Steel Community (Treaty of Paris signed on April 18, 1951, in force on July 23, 1952, expired on July 23, 2002), European Economic Community (Treaty of Rome signed on March 25, 1957, in force on January 1, 1958) and European Atomic Energy Community (Euratom Treaty signed on March 25, 1957, in force on January 1, 1958). The Communities were combined by the Merger Treaty, or Brussels Treaty, signed on April 8, 1965, in force on July 1, 1967 and expired on May 1, 1999 (upon entry into force of the Treaty of Amsterdam). On November 1, 1993, upon entry into force of the Treaty on European Union (Maastricht Treaty), the Communities became the so-called first pillar of the new European Union , while the European Economic Community was renamed to European Community. Upon entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon on December 1, 2009, the European Community and the European Union were merged, being the latter the legal successor to the former.

Organizational acronyms: CFSP: Common Foreign and Security Policy ECB: European Central Bank EEC: European Economic Community ECSC: High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community EEC: European Economic Community EMI: European Monetary Institute Euratom: European Atomic Energy Community; FASP: Foreign Affairs and Security Policy

Look for biographies of the leaders (in Spanish) at CIDOB website.

See also the 27 Member States: Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Ireland, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Spain, Slovakia, Slovenia and Sweden

(*) Merged European Communities and European Union. Presidents of the Parliament (*)

Common Assembly of the ECSC Paul Henri Spaak 10 Sep 1952 - 11 May 1954 (1972) Belgium Alcide De Gasperi 11 May 1954 - 19 Aug 1954 (1954) Italy Giuseppe Pella 29 Nov 1954 - 27 Nov 1956 (1981) Italy Hans Furler 27 Nov 1956 - 19 Mar 1958 (1975) Germany European Parliamentary Assembly Robert Schuman 19 Mar 1958 - 28 Mar 1960 (1963) France Hans Furler 28 Mar 1960 - 27 Mar 1962 (1975) Germany Appointed European Parliament Gaetano Martino 27 Mar 1962 - 21 Mar 1964 (1967) Italy Jean-Pierre Duvieusart 21 Mar 1964 - 24 Sep 1965 (1977) Belgium Victor Leemans 24 Sep 1965 - 7 Mar 1966 (1971) Belgium Alain Poher 7 Mar 1966 - 11 Mar 1969 (1996) France Mario Scelba 11 Mar 1969 - 9 Mar 1971 (1991) Italy Walter Behrendt 9 Mar 1971 - 13 Mar 1973 (1997) Germany Cornelis Berkhouwer 13 Mar 1973 - 11 Mar 1975 (1992) Netherlands Georges Spénale 11 Mar 1975 - 8 Mar 1977 (1983) France Emilio Colombo 8 Mar 1977 - 17 Jul 1979 (2013) Italy Elected European Parliament Simone Veil 17 Jul 1979 - 19 Jan 1982 (2017) France Piet Dankert 19 Jan 1982 - 24 Jul 1984 (2003) Netherlands Pierre Pflimlin 24 Jul 1984 - 20 Jan 1987 (2000) France Henry Plumb 20 Jan 1987 - 25 Jul 1989 (2022) United Kingdom Enrique Barón Crespo 25 Jul 1989 - 14 Jan 1992 Spain Egon Klepsch 14 Jan 1992 - 19 Jul 1994 (2010) Germany Klaus Hänsch 19 Jul 1994 - 14 Jan 1997 Germany José María Gil-Robles 14 Jan 1997 - 20 Jul 1999 (2023) Spain Nicole Fontaine 20 Jul 1999 - 15 Jan 2002 (2018) France Patrick (Pat) Cox 15 Jan 2002 - 20 Jul 2004 Ireland Josep Borrell Fontelles 20 Jul 2004 - 16 Jan 2007 Spain Hans-Gert Pöttering 16 Jan 2007 - 14 Jul 2009 Germany Jerzy Buzek 14 Jul 2009 - 17 Jan 2012 Poland Martin Schulz 17 Jan 2012 - 17 Jan 2017 Germany Antonio Tajani 17 Jan 2017 - 3 Jul 2019 Italy David Sassoli 3 Jul 2019 - 11 Jan 2022 (2022) Italy Roberta Metsola 11 Jan 2022 - Malta (acting to 18 Jan 2022)

(*) From 1952 to 1958 a Common Assembly existed as representative of the national parliaments of the ECSC's six constituent States. In 1958 the organ was upgraded to Parliamentary Assembly to cover the other two European Communities, the EEC and the Euratom. In 1962 it was renamed to the European Parliament.
